sourceDesc.bibl: Mrs. Sanger May Defy Laws Here in Aid of Cause, Chicago Daily Tribune, Apr. 22, 1917, p. 17.

headNote.p: Sanger spoke to a women's only meeting in the afternoon and open meeting in the evening at Chicago's Strand Theatre. She was introduced by Anna Bemis at the afternoon meeting. No complete version of her speech has been found.

docBody.head: Mrs. Sanger May Defy Laws Here in Aid of Cause
Predict Women Will Get the Right to Limit Children

div.p: Mrs. Margaret Sanger, high priestess of the birth control cult in America, yesterday told two audiences at the Strand theater that every woman should have the legal right to determine how many babies she would bring into the world. She said the rich people now practice birth control, and she approved it--not because they were rich but because, she said, woman, whether rich or poor, should have “absolute control of her body.” That, she added was what was coming in the new emancipation of woman throughout the world. She did not impart the specific information--as she did in New York and served a month in jail for it--as to how the women of today could regulate such things. She informed her audiences, however, that if they would communicate with her at her New York address she would see that in some way the desired information got to them. “When I was here last year,” she said, “I had 4,000 inquires on the subject of birth control. All those inquires were answered.”

p.q: Mrs. Sanger spoke to a meeting “for women only” in the afternoon, and went much more into detail than at the night meeting, which was a mixed gathering, the general public being admitted without regard to sex, color, or age. At both meetings representatives of the United States district attorney, State’s Attorney Hoyne, and Chief of Police Schuettler watched closely for infringements of the laws. On several occasions Mrs. Sanger got right up to the edge of the narrow line that separated the audience from specific information as to how to do all these things. Each time she proceeded cautiously and steered away from the danger line with a sort of anti-climax, to the evident regret of her audience. Both audiences were made up almost entirely of her followers, in which representatives of the laboring classes predominated.

div.head: Wedding Ring for Ticket
div.p: One woman, according to the ticket seller, left her wedding ring as security for a $1.50 ticket after she had told him she was the mother of three children but would not get her allowance until today. The ring bore the initials “M. I. C.” under date of June 4, ‘16. Mrs. Edward Bemis, wife of the city’s gas expert, introduced Mrs. Sanger at both meetings with glowing eulogies of the “cause.” Mrs. Sanger has three children and Mrs. Bemis dwelt at some length on the “splendid womanly woman and beautiful mother” who had the courage to “speak out on this subject.” Mrs. Sanger told the women in the afternoon that if they deemed it necessary she would defy the Illinois laws, establish a birth control clinic in the stockyards district and help test the Illinois statutes, which, she said, gave physicians the right to regulate births in certain cases, but denied her the right to give the information which would prevent the “undesired birth.” She spoke for “voluntary motherhood,” drawing a clear distinction between birth control, or non-conception, and abortion. It was to prevent abortions and the attendant ravages, she said, that her scheme had been sent forth the world.

div.head: “Woman Demand Freedom”
div.p: “Women,” she said, “long have been the brunt of unwilling motherhood. They now demand the freedom of their bodies. Woman has been, since history began, a mere breeding machine for children who fill our hospitals, our insane asylums, our feeble-minded institutions, and our prisons. The world is full of undesired babies because of ignorance of how to prevent them.
“There are 250,000 abortions in the United States every year, with 50,000 deaths resulting therefrom. Four out of every seven women suffering with tuberculosis die because of pregnancy.

“In Illinois, at your Geneva home for wayward girls, 85 percent of the inmates come from families averaging nine children or more, while 50 percent of these are feeble minded. Last year in New York 10,000 feeble minded girls were living in prostitution.

“The wealthy districts of our large cities yield one-third the number of births the poor districts do. The rich woman has the right to say for herself how many children she shall bear and, having the information and the means, she can carry out her ideas. It’s the poor and ignorant mother who peoples the world with undesired, unwanted children.” Mrs. Sanger said she went to jail in New York because she refused to promise to respect the law.
“I would rather take thirty days in the workhouse,” she said, “than promise to respect such a law when there are 8,000 abortions annually in New York state.”
